Generating the *When Dimension*

2023-12-26

Source: vignettes/when.Rmd
when.Rmd

Introduction

The When Dimension plays a fundamental role in Multidimensional Systems, it allows us to express when the analysed focus of attention have occurred.

In Kimball (1996), the term “Time Dimension” was used to call this dimension, regardless of its granularity. In Kimball and Ross (2013) it is indicated that for 10 years the term “Date Dimension” has been used to call this dimension at the date level and “Time Dimension” or “Time-of-day Dimension” is used when the granularity is the time. However, the term “Time Dimension” has continued to be used regardless of granularity, as it is in Adamson (2010). For this reason here we refer to this dimension as “When Dimension”, a term independent of granularity.

Although conceptually the date and time can be represented together in a single dimension, in ROLAP (Relational On-Line Analytical Processing) systems, it is common to implement these concepts separately, sometimes in separate tables “to avoid a row count explosion in the date dimension” (Kimball and Ross 2013).

Likewise, in Kimball and Ross (2013) these dimensions are considered static dimensions: they are built at the beginning of the project for the period under consideration and are referenced when adding the instances to the fact table. As mentioned there: “Typically, these dimensions are built in an afternoon with a spreadsheet.”

The purpose of the when package is to assist in the implementation of the When Dimension in Multidimensional Systems implemented on a ROLAP star database, regardless of its granularity, with the following features:

  • It supports the generation of tables with the granularity needed (second, minute, hour, date, week, month or year).

  • We consider separate tables for time data and data obtained from date to avoid a row count explosion if a single table were used.

  • It can be used to generate tables statically, indicating a period, or dynamically, indicating data series.

  • In addition to attributes at the selected granularity, other attributes can be added at coarser granularity to facilitate querying.

The rest of this document is structured as follows: First, . The following is an illustrative example of how the package works, to show usage of features it offers. Finally, the document ends with conclusions and bibliography.

library(when)

Conclusions

rolap package offers a set of operations that allow us to transform tables into star databases. From several star databases you can define a constellation with conformed dimensions.

Operations have been designed to be intuitive and easy to use. The result greatly facilitates the data transformation process for the exposed situation.

The implementation of the multidimensional database obtained can be exported to work with multidimensional analysis tools on spreadsheets or RDBMS.

Bibliography

Adamson, Christopher. 2010. Star Schema: The Complete Reference. McGraw Hill Professional.
Kimball, Ralph. 1996. The Data Warehouse Toolkit: Practical Techniques for Building Dimensional Data Warehouses. John Wiley & Sons.
Kimball, Ralph, and Margy Ross. 2013. The Data Warehouse Toolkit: The Definitive Guide to Dimensional Modeling. John Wiley & Sons.
